children.subject:
Thx Mongo for your thoughts.

I speak only for myself. Note that there was only one substantive comment on the @5046 post, by Kunal Mishra. If there was any invitation for comment before @5046 was posted, perhaps on Facebook, I didn't see it. I don't think there's been enough public discussion with input by students on whether @5046 was a good policy. The question of student input on department changes is a broader one, and out of scope for this I think. 

What do you think about @5046, in particular?

Responding to Mong's point about student input: firstly, thanks for filling out the 2017-18 EECS Undergrad Survey!

Secondly, as Department Relations for HKN and someone who worked on the survey with Nicole, I'd like to point out that student orgs and the department do act upon the survey. Not only do student orgs come together to update faculty on the state of undergrad affairs using its data, but there are town halls organized to elicit more feedback and ideas to move forward (e.g. @3418 @3558), as well as other department actions taken that are informed by the survey. The survey is taken very seriously. Nevertheless, the point you make about transparency (or perhaps visibility?) is a fair one, and I think it's a valuable one to keep in mind in these broader discussions.

EECS 101 is now more like Course Advice on Facebook. Its for students to help each other and what they think of others' views/opinions about classes/schedules from their own experiences. If you would like official help, cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu is always available for you, and has been available before Piazza even existed.

I feel it is probably overburdening for the staff to cater to requests from both the advising email and the Piazza. Note that the email is the official agent set up for the purpose and I feel that it is more apt to have an email as an official source since it is more concrete. You may feel otherwise (I understand that Piazza is far more accessible than writing an individual email; other students who have the same questions can benefit, etc.) but that point is open for discussion.

As I said below too

"I understand that Piazza is far more accessible than writing an individual email; other students who have the same questions can benefit, etc."
Exactly this! Why not just use this Piazza instead of cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu? If it is a private concern, mark the post as private. Otherwise, everyone can benefit from the answer.
Maybe I'm being naive and there are logistical burdens with this approach, but I'm not seeing them.

I kinda agree with you on this too. The email has a response time of 3-5 business days while the Piazza is much quicker, effective and you get to see the viewpoints of both students and staff at one place, which is extremely convenient. That is why I had remarked that this is the point that is up for discussion.

My post below was concerning the unabashed allegations of Thomas against the staff, after incorrectly interpreting the current situation, that's all.

Here's the thing though: if we were to start using Piazza alone instead of cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu, then the response times on Piazza would also be 3-5 business days. This is because there would always be a back log of Piazza posts that advisors would need to deal with. But that is still a better solution than emails. 

So basically, I'm not suggesting using Piazza entirely because I think that will improve response times, I'm suggesting it simply because people will be able to see what the replies to other students' queries are.

What is not being understood is the fact that the staff did try out managing both the email and the Piazza, but felt overburdened and therefore, cut short on answering questions on this forum. 

Also, in case the switch to Piazza is made,

the department needs to make it clear that this is the only official agent for communication between staff and students, which could be difficult and take some time. I still have friends in EECS who do not have any clue about EECS 101 but they do know that there exists an email they can use to communicate directly with staff.

What is not being understood is the fact that the staff did try out managing both the email and the Piazza, but felt overburdened and therefore, cut short on answering questions on this forum. 

Which is precisely why I'm suggesting using only Piazza. 

the department needs to make it clear that this is the only official agent for communication between staff and students, which could be difficult and take some time. I still have friends in EECS who do not have any clue about EECS 101 but they do know that there exists an email they can use to communicate directly with staff.

Sounds like an easy fix using an auto-responder that says "Hey! We're not responding to this email anymore. Post on the EECS 101 Piazza. Here's how to join it."
I really like the solutions you have proposed Mudit and I'm in support! Let's hope someone from the department reads through all of this and takes it into account.

Piazza only is an interesting idea. I think bots could augment a lot of the advising staff's work, like marking obvious duplicates. I'm not sure how much work it would take to set a bot up. 

Mentioned in original post: 

"3. The use of bots should be explored.

 

Certain questions exhaust resources because they are so common and easily searchable. These can be addressed with automated bots. Maybe course staff for 61a or 61b could implement a system for their Piazzas which could be repurposed for EECS 101."

I believe 61A and B have tried implementing bots for figuring out duplicates, but it's not as easy as it may seem. Just because a post has "EE16A" and "Math 54" doesn't necessarily mean that it is a duplicate of "Is EE16A a substitute for Math 54?", because perhaps the student is asking about a double major requirement or something.

Also, I think the number of duplicate questions does not really justify the need to make bots just to figure out duplicates. I don't think it would contribute significantly to anyone's workload anyway.

Re: "Also, in case the switch to Piazza is made ... communicate directly with staff."

I wager there are as many students who are unaware of the existence of EECS 101 as there are students who are unaware of @5046's effect on EECS 101.

@Mudit,

I don't think bots are limited to marking duplicates. For example, if they got a question with "EE16A" and "Math 54" they could just dump the relevant FAQ sections and hope that the question is answered. If not, somebody would have had to answer it manually anyway, if yes, then great, we reduced work. This does necessitate a broad and updated FAQ.

I don't think many students consider this Piazza the official word anyway (unless they get an official answer for their question).
Many of them could be unaware of the fact that the responses they are getting may be inaccurate though.
Boost to Jessie's point. If you care about this, do the department survey. Include your thoughts there.

I agree that changes are necessary for this big institution to maintain the level of education. I DISagree with the approach of this post in that it places one sided demands on the department asking for radical standardization without offering representative student opinions. I encourage department and students body such as HKN and TBP to discuss and cooperate in these hard times.

On a more personal note, I do feel frustrated at certain aspects of this big institution that belies  its reputation (enrollment, packed office hour). I filled out the hkn eecs survey but I am dubious how that will change anything. Perhaps department could be more transparent when pushing for changes? Also, if a student sees that certain aspect of a class is lacking, can we have a better substantial mechanism to improve instead of mere surveys.

Anyway, just my thoughts. Let us peacefully discuss.

Actually, I don't really understand why emailing cs-advising should be the norm, considering that so many students have the same questions. "Is math 54 a substitute for EE16AB" has been asked numerous times. Now imagine that same question being directed to cs-advising tons of times. It doesn't sound like the scalable solution here. 

I get it, some questions are indeed for students. Questions about difficulty of courses should probably just be answered by students. Questions about "chances of getting in" are mostly pointless because the answer is always "idk, probably if you're in the top 10% of the waitlist". But there are legitimate questions that I do think should just be answered on Piazza, and any emails related to those questions should be redirected to Piazza, not vice versa. 

If a student requires some sort of one-on-one situation reply, then those should go via email. "I submitted X to graduate, but now I want to take an extra semester." This requires someone to actually look into one person's individual situation, in which case, email is the way to go. But for everything else --- why not Piazza?

Actually, taking this one step further, why not just get rid of cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu entirely, and simply use Piazza. If it is a private concern, mark the post private. If not, then let everyone see and benefit from the answer. I'm just wondering what the problems with this approach are...
Please see my response in the above followup.

Do note that questions like "Is math 54 a substitute for EE16AB" have been asked multiple times on this Piazza itself yet people keep asking them (without digging through the archives, just for their convenience).

Yeah, but students are pretty good at helping mark those as duplicates. I'm just saying -- imagine that on Piazza, where everyone can see the information, there are duplicates. How many duplicate emails would there be?

I mean, this is precisely the reason that large courses have adopted Piazza as the primary means of communication instead of emails. I think it makes sense for advising to follow through too, considering that it is targeted towards a much larger audience than a large course.

Thanks for your opinion OP anon - whether or not you agree with me, I am happy that there is discussion on the issue of @5046.

Nonetheless, you are incorrect - you have failed to understand what makes something official or unofficial. As Mudit is pointing out, one option for the staff would be to simply transition everything over to Piazza. Why is email "official" and piazza "unofficial"? Simply because the advising staff deem one official, and the other unofficial, or because the students perceive one as official, and vice versa. I do not mean that this distinction is trivial, rather, it is a design decision and should be optimized accordingly. I am comfortable saying that Piazza was "official" inasmuch as students perceived it so - certainly if Nicole posts something on EECS 101 in the instructor box, I think we would all consider it official. Indeed, @5046's transition to making EECS 101 unofficial implicitly recognizes that it was serving an official function before. This is a student-run forum now, but it does not have to be.

It is generous for the staff to continue posting on Piazza even after @5046. I think that this may actually be, counterintuitively, a bad idea. Students don't know whether there is a lack of response to their question because the staff are operating under @5046, or because they should wait. This becomes a variable-reinforcement schedule, where students are sparsely rewarded for the behavior of posting on Piazza. As a result, students become conditioned to posting on Piazza, regardless of the official @5046 policy. 

I would like to point out that, per Lily on the @5046 post, there are supposed to be "6 or 7 [peer advisers] this semester [who] will continue to monitor and answer questions." Part of my original @5046 Considered Harmful post points out that it's unclear to students who exactly these peer advisers are, and if a comment is made by a student who is a peer adviser. 

Mudit mentions that cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu does not scale - I think he is correct. Consider the growth in LSCS majors. There are currently 1,203, and the growth is very fast, if not exponential. Suppose that 1/3 of CS-intended declare. Based on the most common EECs 101 posts, it is reasonable to believe that those who have not declared ask at least as many questions as those who have declared. So the total population of students asking questions is $$EECS + CS_{declared}~~~~+ CS_{undeclared}~~~~$$, or 1343 + 1203 + (2 * 1203) = 4350.5, let's round to 4350 for that even number. Suppose each person only consumes 20 minutes of advising time per semester. That's over 1305 hours of advising per semester. Even if these figures are rough, I think the order of magnitude is defensible. What happens when the number of LSCS kids doubles? Will the number of advisers scale pro rata? I do not think the budget will allow for that. Future growth must be in consideration.

@Thomas

You are trying to move your argument towards the fact that Piazza has been made "unofficial" and how you feel (alongside Mudit, myself and many others) that Piazza should become the official agent for advising.

My post was concerning your unabashed allegations against the staff/Steven Bi/all student answerers, after incorrectly interpreting the current situation. You claimed that the staff was obligated to "monitor" questions on Piazza (at a "minimum") and that is just blatantly wrong. You also questioned the correctness of various posts made by students, forgetting that inaccuracy is a given for a student-run advising forum.

You also seem to have incomplete knowledge. Peer advisors are students appointed by the department specifically for peer advising. They are trained and have knowledge to handle most questions by the students. In short, they are considered "official".

About your argument regarding staff continuing to post in spite of @5046 being a bad idea, would you rather have NO involvement at all from staff on this Piazza or would you rather want to reap the benefits of whatever time they are taking out of their busy schedule for this involvement? I believe the staff is doing the best it can and fully utilizing the limited resources they have in hand.

"@ Thomas..."

Ah, I see your confusion. This post is titled @5046 considered harmful - I am well aware that @5046 makes EECS 101 obsolete, that's what I'm saying should be reverted. That is why this post is titled "@5046 considered harmful". 

Please also re-read my original post for the section on peer advisers: "I have not seen around Piazza the “6-7 peer advisers” who are supposed to monitor and answer questions. Perhaps their visibility could be increased with an instructor endorsement." and my prior comment: " there are suppose [sic] to be "6 or 7 [peer advisers] this semester [who] will continue to monitor and answer questions." Part of my original @5046 Considered Harmful post points out that it's unclear to students who exactly these peer advisers are, and if a comment is made by a student who is a peer adviser." I know that there are peer advisers. I don't know who is a peer adviser without reference to the website. And even when a peer adviser posts, it's still hard to know that they posted (e.g. if they posted in the student box and their name got buried).

Re: "About your argument..."

Please reread "It is generous .... regardless of the official @5046 policy. "

Yes, I think Piazza should be all or nothing. It is really confusing - at least for me - whether an a question is not getting a response because it's getting @5046'd or because the advisers haven't had a chance to look at it. Furthermore, the impression that advisers are lurking on the Piazza engenders a belief - at least for me - that incorrect information will be correct (see the list of examples in the original post). So there is a lot of ambiguity on which answers are correct because there is ambiguity on the status of EECS 101. Again, I think Piazza should be all-or-nothing, in the sense that advisers can create more confusion by answer some posts and not others.
Peer advisors are enrolled on this Piazza as instructors. For example, Lily is a peer-advisor.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but Lily Zhang is a "CS Student Affairs Advisor" per https://eecs.berkeley.edu/people/staff/student-affairs-staff. She has an office in 379 Soda, and I presume on that basis that she is staff, not a student. 

This only highlights the confusion over the role of peer-advisers on Piazza (I'm not speaking to whether their in-person tabling is ineffective).

I don't think making Piazza "all-or-nothing" is a viable solution. Someone like Professor Sahai probably does not have the time to comb through all the EECS 101 Piazza posts for the day. The same goes for the advisors, who are busy with their other commitments. Unfortunately, you do not seem to understand this subtle but important fact.

At best, we can just assume @5046 and if we do end up with a staff response, we'd be in luck. Else, we'd have to depend on the student responses (while knowing that they could be inaccurate). I'm not sure if you have noticed but the staff does its try its best to look through this Piazza and answer the most important questions with their response (even after the students have given a correct response) every 2-3 days in spite of @5046. Isn't that commendable?

Why is making it all or nothing not a viable solution? If "all" is not possible, "nothing" certainly is. 

The question of whether advisers ought to post on EECS 101 in spite of @5046 has nothing to do with commendability. I repeat:  

"It is generous for the staff to continue posting on Piazza even after @5046. I think that this may actually be, counterintuitively, a bad idea. Students don't know whether there is a lack of response to their question because the staff are operating under @5046, or because they should wait. This becomes a variable-reinforcement schedule, where students are sparsely rewarded for the behavior of posting on Piazza. As a result, students become conditioned to posting on Piazza, regardless of the official @5046 policy."

I distinguish between Professor Sahai's posts and adviser's posts - the former is advice qua personal wisdom and the latter advice qua official policy. Delivery of the first on a variable-reinforcement schedule is a delight, while similar dispatch of the second is ambiguous. 

In an ideal world, yes, we would have Piazza and email and all kinds of things. I understand that the advisers are not obligated, under @5046, to respond to anything on Piazza, and do so voluntarily. I have personally made use of the in-person advice scheduling and can testify that it is very helpful. I am saying that, counter-intuitively, it would be better to post no responses, rather than a few.

Pardon my incorrect word usage, I meant "less suitable" instead of "viable".

Alright, that's just your opinion I guess. Should've assumed your stubbornness earlier.

For me personally, it is quite helpful to see advisors skim through this Piazza and respond to at least few of the posts rather than their complete absence and I would definitely not prefer them not posting at all. They're trying their best to help us as much as they can and I cannot discourage them from that.

If your requirements of avoiding "counter-intuitiveness", "variable-reinforcement" and the great confusion over "omg is my question gonna be answered by staff" are more important than whatever effort the staff is currently giving to this Piazza, its just your choice and I have to respect that.

Also, just to let you know, Professor Sahai is an integral member of the EECS department and plays a major role in the policy-making. His answers are not limited to his "personal wisdom", rather he is representative of the policies of the department as well.

I just wanna chime in to say that not all of us are in support of Thomas' "all or nothing" idea. While I am certainly for an "all" idea where we use Piazza exclusively instead of email for advising, I still do appreciate the occasional responses here. I don't think there's any confusion about who to trust on Piazza here. Yes, sometimes there are incorrect responses, but they are mostly corrected.

@Most recent anon, my impression of Thomas's points is that, when staff members do keep posting on this Piazza, it makes the "status" or the "purpose" of the Piazza unclear. Is this an "official" platform if staff members are posting on it? Is it just, as mentioned, peer-answered "Course Advice" from FB but on Piazza? It makes it harder for people to tell how much they can trust the information being given - not everyone will realize how many grains of salt to take for any given reply, particularly with the confusion over who is or isn't a peer-adviser (still not sure if they're marked as instructors or not...?), the misleading "instructor-endorsed answerer" Piazza feature, etc. (This is probably a rehashing of a number of points made by Thomas and Mudit.)

I don't think Thomas is trying to undermine or undervalue the work staff is giving to this Piazza - I think most of us really appreciate it. But it does muddy the waters, and it does make this Piazza an... inconsistent (?) source of information, diluting its usefulness. EECS 101 is a useful system, esp when staff make posts, but there are fair critiques to be made of it currently. For example, what can/should be done achieve a level of consistent quality.

"LSCS & EECS advising staff ought respond to, and at minimum monitor, advising-related posts on EECS 101. (@5046 for reference)"

You have clearly misread @5046. Moreover, this is an extremely harsh statement - EECS 101 is an unofficial forum and the staff is, by no means, compelled to "monitor" advising-related posts.

According to your reference post, advising related posts would no longer be handled on EECS 101, effectively rendering this Piazza a student-run forum (with regards to advising). If you would like to get advice from the staff, please email cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu.

I do not understand your concerns. This is a student-run forum and if you choose to ask a question here related to advising, you should be expecting an answer from your peers, which may or may not accurate and you should be wary of that fact.

Even after the announcement, I am grateful that the staff has continued to respond to posts on this Piazza (albeit not so comprehensively anymore), especially Nicole and Professor Sahai.

Agree. Thomas, maybe you do so because EECS advisors have done that a couple of times previously. (I believe) They actually hope students to ask such specific advising questions through email or in-person, but what do you mean?

The specific instance where the EECS advisor Nicole did it, it was only because the student requested an answer directly from the staff and the Nicole simply pointed out that staff advising is not done via Piazza.

Copied from a previous comment - "It is generous for the staff to continue posting on Piazza even after @5046. I think that this may actually be, counterintuitively, a bad idea. Students don't know whether there is a lack of response to their question because the staff are operating under @5046, or because they should wait. This becomes a variable-reinforcement schedule, where students are sparsely rewarded for the behavior of posting on Piazza. As a result, students become conditioned to posting on Piazza, regardless of the official @5046 policy."

The advising staff have replied with @5046 previously, see @5827. Most of my responses that are just "@5046" are in response to student queries that don't have another answer, or do not have an instructor response. @5046 is not pinned and it's possible students missed it - I think they should know why there is not a response to their post. I'm not trying to be disrespectful, but to provide explanation. There is too much ambiguity. 

OP, I will gladly stop posting @5046 if you in return fully answer every query I have @5046'd.
Maybe you shouldn't @5046 in the student response. It marks it as resolved, and other students might have more constructive answers.
Good point, I forgot that it marks it as resolved.

I don't know why you're feeling compelled to answer the question with @5046 if you know that it is not constructive.

I think avoiding to do so would be more helpful for the students involved and everyone else really, cuz right now, its a mere nuisance.

see prev "@5046 is not pinned and it's possible students missed it - I think they should know why there is not a response to their post. I'm not trying to be disrespectful, but to provide explanation. There is too much ambiguity.

Read again, it is NOT constructive and does not help the student in any way.

Also, if someone is not getting an answer for their post for a long time, it is usually the case that their question is off-topic (not related to EECS, very specific to their situation, etc.)
BTW, I see @5046 is pinned.

I have stopped @5046'ing posts. You are correct, @5046 is pinned; it was below 13 other pinned posts so I didn't see it. It was wrong of me to inadvertently mark such posts as resolved by answering in the student box with @5046 - sorry about that. 

I think this discussion on whether it would be better to inform students about @5046 or not is a vacuous debate and detracts from the question of whether @5046 is a good idea. I have stopped @5046'ing posts.
Thank you

@Thomas,

This is directed directly to you.

I do not understand why you have been answering student queries recenlty with your reference to @5046. This is extremely disrespectful as the person who asked the question did not necessarily elicit a response from the staff. Please refrain from doing so.

I think your point about creating a formal "Piazza etiquette" post would be helpful. It isn't strictly enforceable per se, but if nothing else, one could reference it in the followups to remind people to, for example, try searching for their query, think about how on-topic their question is, etc.
My take on etiquette @5851. Agree with you, etiquette is important and I hope that we as a community improve on it.

In regards to instructor endorsed responders,

I am not quite sure that the advisors can do anything about verifying the credibility of these students because this is a Piazza feature- if an instructor sees a good student response, the instructor endorses it and the student gets a check mark. Regulating this would require instructors to not endorse answers they believe are correct, which detracts from helpfulness of answers in individual posts. 

In regards to updating FAQs,

In my experience, department websites tend to contain important information so it would be a bit unnecessary to repeat information on Piazza. Further, searching on Piazza can often yield the information for which one is looking, which is where you have suggested bots. However, I do not think the department should take on the responsibility of creating a new system simply because students do not know how to search the existing database for answers. 

In regards to receiving credible answers, 

If one has a question that desperately requires accurate information, I do not think that Piazza is the correct platform. It is my opinion that students should turn to directly interacting with the advisors, i.e. not through Piazza. I understand that it may be hard to receive a speedy response from advisors and as such turn to Piazza for answers. I have always taken non-instructor responses on Piazza with a grain of salt if I am not able to corroborate it through departmental information but I can see that this sentiment is not held by everyone. 

Overall, I see the points you are making. However, I want to point out that many of the "issues" with Piazza have arisen because of the students- if students were better at searching for information on their own, then Piazza would not be the giant mess that it is and instructors would likely be more willing to regularly monitor it. If we all make an effort to make the posts on Piazza less trivial than perhaps the previous policy can be reinstituted. Just my opinion however, but I think generally, not just for EECS 101, students should consider having some Piazza etiquette.
+1, especially to points about potential (in)efficiency

+1. If answering questions on Piazza is too taxing, I think staff should prefer to leave Facebook completely and rededicate resources to Piazza. 

1. Piazza has forum-focused features Facebook does not have, like search, marking duplicates, student boxes, anonymity, private posts, etc

2. Facebook devolves into people tagging each other, Piazza does not

3. Lots of people aren't on Facebook. The reasons why people aren't on Facebook don't apply to Piazza. Piazza use is required for some classes, so it's reasonable to require the use of Piazza for EECS / CS majors. I don't think it's reasonable to require students have a Facebook account to ensure access to their education. 

4. Piazza is dedicated education software, but Facebook is not. That means that asking Piazza to make certain changes is more viable than asking Facebook to. And, there is no guarantee that Facebook will continue to offer certain features into the future, which is reasonable to expect of Piazza.
+1 on efficiency and toxicity
+1 Definitely agree with Thomas' points. I think that Piazza should be the full solution rather than looking to the email features or using fb.

+1 Piazza seems much more appropriate for these matters. Facebook is cool but not the right platform imo for all the reasons mentioned. Email seems the worst....everyone with the same question will send an individual email (they even admitted this @881). Can the admins please clarify why they chose email to be the preferred communication tool? Very interested to know.

Also I agree with anon that things have gotten kind of toxic. Some people seem to have gotten insulted by OP's original question, and responded to him in a manner that was even more toxic. Please consider my take on etiquette @5851 in the future.

Am I the only one here who thinks that Thomas has a point here? Specifically to the topic of the peer advisors--there should be done something here to make this a little more clear to who is a peer advisor and who is not. Maybe at least a list of "staff approved" peer advisors or something somewhere? Forgive me if this already exists and I just haven't been able to find it.

As a more general point though, Berkeley is a large and confusing school and students are generally left to sink or swim. There is already enough confusion about official (and unofficial) department policies--for example, (1) the number of friends I have who've said "If I knew Math 54 was going to be lifted as a requirement, ..." and (2) the historical conflicting messages from faculty and departmental staff regarding when/how to take the 16 series (not sure if this is so much of a problem anymore, but I remember this being a pretty big thing a couple years back). 

In order to avoid similar confusion, we need to have a clear mindset of which mediums are for official policy, and which are for unofficial advice. I see the EECS Facebook page, Piazza 101, email, and talking to departmental staff directly as the four main methods of getting EECS-related advice at this school, in order of increasing officialness (if that's a word). However, when the department inconsistently becomes involved in the former two (FB and Piazza), it starts blurring the lines. Students need to know where to go for advice they can trust, and I'm not sure if that's true at the present moment.

For example, it is strange to me that departmental announcements and information about enrollment will be continue to be posted on Piazza, but we won't get official responses about anything else. It is also strange that in the face of a growing student population, the response is to opt to have official avenues of advice veer towards email or in-person solutions, rather than embracing the efficiency of using an online platform. 

This is not intended to be directed specifically at the EECS department, EECS students, or other responders to this post. In fact, I find a lot of the discussion on this thread mildly toxic (and hope I am not contributing to this toxicity). I understand that the EECS department (and the university as a whole) is already stretched thin in terms of resources, and I understand that logistically it may be hard to monitor multiple websites AND respond to emails AND do everything else that the staff does, which is why I think the peer advisor solution is actually quite a clever one. However, I think that the decision to move away from official advice on Piazza and move towards more individualized advising through email or in-person counseling is the wrong direction for the department, and this decision may end up causing more inefficiency and confusion.

Yeah, I agree that certain types of questions aren’t directed to advisors. IF advisors decide to move to a Piazza-only system for advising, I just wanted to point out that posts can be archived! 

So for instance, say that advisors were to start monitoring posts without an instructor endorsement and/or answer on this Piazza, starting from the oldest post. Then they hit a post which they can’t answer — say something about peer advice, they can simply archive the post and move to the next one and it’ll not appear on their Piazza again.

There are certain types of questions on EECS 101 that I feel are not necessarily directed to the advisers to answer in the first place. I don't believe that advisors have personal experience to answer questions regarding course preparation/difficulty, and research advice. Rather, these types of questions are more directed to TAs, students and professors to answer first who have had direct first-hand experience. (The types of questions that advisers answer are logistical ones, like grades/enrollment/time conflicts/hiring.)

Professor Sahai has done a great job answering questions, but in my view he shouldn't be the only one. I wish if we had more profs contributing and answering questions, especially about research and career goals. Can prof. DeNero, Hug, Dragan, Rao, Ayazifar, etc. have a more active role in advising students?

It's still interesting that despite the announcement the admins are still very active on piazza and devote considerable effort to helping students. I appreciate their service and I think we should be thankful for their hard work :)
yes! thank you

In the followups of @5046 , the advisers noted many questions on EECS101 Piazza are answerable through quick Google searches. I think the idea is that email, being more formal and 1-on-1, prompts the student to think about doing her/his own research online (Google, official Berkeley website, past EECS101 posts [seriously, use the search bar!] ) before asking a lazy question.

It's also not in the interest of advisers to be flooded with similar emails.  Thus, if many students are writing emails with the same questions, then the advisers would likely make a pinned post on EECS101 or update the pinned FAQ.

Also, +1 to a follow-up mentioned above: a lot of the questions on EECS101 aren't suitable for Advisers to answer, anyways. They are more suited for other students or possibly any Professors who lurk around here.

In conclusion, I treat any Adviser responses to random posts here as something lucky; advisers should not be obligated to use this unofficial Piazza in my opinion.

history.content:
LSCS & EECS advising staff ought respond to, and at minimum monitor, advising-related posts on EECS 101. [Edit: to clarify, I think @5046 has problems]

I love Steven Bi (Who is Steven Bi? @5661). He's probably saved all of our butts at some point. Why is important advising information being dispensed by somebody who is not, as far as I can tell, formally affiliated with the department?

My intention is not to raise pitchforks against Steven - he is merely the example par excellence - but rather ask why responsibility has fallen to volunteers. There is nothing wrong with people volunteering their time, but there is bad smell when advising decamps and students start to rely on third parties for information, and, more critically, make decisions based on information from third parties, likely without validating that information first.

Of course, we should be verifying any information we make decisions off of - but students are human, and under a lot of time pressure, and few will do so. No PEBCAK here; this is faulty design. Who takes responsibility if something incorrect is posted by a third party? God bless Steven but even Steven can be uneven.

It's great to have a forum to ask our peers questions of a subjective nature. It is deeply worrying when we don’t know if we can trust the information on Piazza.

Suggestions:

Ideally, revert the policy in @5046. If that is not feasible:

1. Formalize the use of instructor-endorsed responders on EECS 101.

The implications of the checkmarks need to be well-defined. If an instructor-endorsed responder replies to a post, how do we know whether they are saying something as an individual or in a more official capacity?

Furthermore, what happens when somebody who is instructor-endorsed says something on EECS 101 that conflicts with what is said in a course Piazza? The course Piazza should take precedence, but this will undoubtedly cause a lot of uncertainty that could be avoided.

It’s also unclear how somebody gets the checkmark. I have not seen around Piazza the “6-7 peer advisers” who are supposed to monitor and answer questions. Perhaps their visibility could be increased with an instructor endorsement.

2. If there are instructor-endorsed responders on EECS 101, students have the right to know who they are and why we should trust them.

I fully support Steven answering questions on Piazza - however, for me to have full trust in his answers, it is necessary for me to know who he is. Here's an example where having an instructor-endorsed responder clarified who to trust in the comments @5467.

3. If there are instructor-endorsed responders on EECS 101, there must be accountability for their responses.

Specifically, if incorrect information is posted, students must be able to trust that that information will be corrected.

  • Here is an example of a question with a student response that was not technically incorrect but was largely useless: @3240. This correction would not necessarily happen under @5046.
  • Here are some examples of questions with an incorrect student response that was appropriately corrected by advisers: @5839, @5710 (in the comments), @4036, @3395, @2976, @2485 (in the comments), @1987, @936. These correction would not necessarily happen under @5046, and deal with questions like satisfying the H/SS requirement for EECS or even the GPA requirement for declaring LSCS.
  • Here is an example of when Steven Bi was incorrect: @5251, second comment (promptly corrected). I repeat that I am very grateful for Steven, but he shouldn't have to shoulder this burden completely.

To be clear - I am empathetic to the financial pressures the department is under. However, if we resort to measures such as instructor-endorsed responders to alleviate this pressure, they can't be mere band-aids and must be well-defined.

In lieu of, or in supplement to, instructor-endorsed responders:

1. FAQs should be updated.

@5046 refers to an FAQ on the EECS website.

  • This FAQ does not include such frequently asked questions as: Is 110 an acceptable substitute? What classes are webcast this semester? How do the waitlists work for lower divs?
  • This FAQ does not include useful sources like @5008.

2. If FAQs are used, all answers should be tagged with when they were last updated.

Requirements and other things change frequently. For example, in response to the question "My question is not on this list, what do I do?" the FAQ suggests checking EECS 101.

3. The use of bots should be explored.

Certain questions exhaust resources because they are so common and easily searchable. These can be addressed with automated bots. Maybe course staff for 61a or 61b could implement a system for their Piazzas which could be repurposed for EECS 101.

Relata:

@5851, @5877, @5865

history.content:
LSCS & EECS advising staff ought respond to, and at minimum monitor, advising-related posts on EECS 101. (@5046 for reference)

I love Steven Bi (Who is Steven Bi? @5661). He's probably saved all of our butts at some point. Why is important advising information being dispensed by somebody who is not, as far as I can tell, formally affiliated with the department?

My intention is not to raise pitchforks against Steven - he is merely the example par excellence - but rather ask why responsibility has fallen to volunteers. There is nothing wrong with people volunteering their time, but there is bad smell when advising decamps and students start to rely on third parties for information, and, more critically, make decisions based on information from third parties, likely without validating that information first.

Of course, we should be verifying any information we make decisions off of - but students are human, and under a lot of time pressure, and few will do so. No PEBCAK here; this is faulty design. Who takes responsibility if something incorrect is posted by a third party? God bless Steven but even Steven can be uneven.

It's great to have a forum to ask our peers questions of a subjective nature. It is deeply worrying when we don’t know if we can trust the information on Piazza.

Suggestions:

Ideally, revert the policy in @5046. If that is not feasible:

1. Formalize the use of instructor-endorsed responders on EECS 101.

The implications of the checkmarks need to be well-defined. If an instructor-endorsed responder replies to a post, how do we know whether they are saying something as an individual or in a more official capacity?

Furthermore, what happens when somebody who is instructor-endorsed says something on EECS 101 that conflicts with what is said in a course Piazza? The course Piazza should take precedence, but this will undoubtedly cause a lot of uncertainty that could be avoided.

It’s also unclear how somebody gets the checkmark. I have not seen around Piazza the “6-7 peer advisers” who are supposed to monitor and answer questions. Perhaps their visibility could be increased with an instructor endorsement.

2. If there are instructor-endorsed responders on EECS 101, students have the right to know who they are and why we should trust them.

I fully support Steven answering questions on Piazza - however, for me to have full trust in his answers, it is necessary for me to know who he is. Here's an example where having an instructor-endorsed responder clarified who to trust in the comments @5467.

3. If there are instructor-endorsed responders on EECS 101, there must be accountability for their responses.

Specifically, if incorrect information is posted, students must be able to trust that that information will be corrected.

  • Here is an example of a question with a student response that was not technically incorrect but was largely useless: @3240. This correction would not necessarily happen under @5046.
  • Here are some examples of questions with an incorrect student response that was appropriately corrected by advisers: @5710 (in the comments), @4036, @3395, @2976, @2485 (in the comments), @1987, @936. These correction would not necessarily happen under @5046, and deal with questions like satisfying the H/SS requirement for EECS or even the GPA requirement for declaring LSCS.
  • Here is an example of when Steven Bi was incorrect: @5251, second comment (promptly corrected). I repeat that I am very grateful for Steven, but he shouldn't have to shoulder this burden completely.

To be clear - I am empathetic to the financial pressures the department is under. However, if we resort to measures such as instructor-endorsed responders to alleviate this pressure, they can't be mere band-aids and must be well-defined.

In lieu of, or in supplement to, instructor-endorsed responders:

1. FAQs should be updated.

@5046 refers to an FAQ on the EECS website.

  • This FAQ does not include such frequently asked questions as: Is 110 an acceptable substitute? What classes are webcast this semester? How do the waitlists work for lower divs?
  • This FAQ does not include useful sources like @5008.

2. If FAQs are used, all answers should be tagged with when they were last updated.

Requirements and other things change frequently. For example, in response to the question "My question is not on this list, what do I do?" the FAQ suggests checking EECS 101.

3. The use of bots should be explored.

Certain questions exhaust resources because they are so common and easily searchable. These can be addressed with automated bots. Maybe course staff for 61a or 61b could implement a system for their Piazzas which could be repurposed for EECS 101.
